computerZone.name: 2017 Graduate Capstone Gallery
computerZone.description: 3 Games - PrincessCape A puzzle platformer where the princess decides she can save herself. Princess Elwynn finds the power of a magical cape, speedy boots, magnetic gloves and herself. - Gloom Box Use music to alter the world and solve puzzles. Mash up music to discover new abilities. - Y.A.W. (Yet Another World) A V.R. simulation of a planetoid that responds to your exploration. Discover creatures and features as the world comes to life.
computerZone.exhibitors: Elouise Oyzon, Arun Krishnakumar, Jeffery Kelly, Anthony Zalar, Chen Yang, Reuben Brenner-Adams, Stein Astor Fernandez

computerZone.name: Al Biles & GenJam
computerZone.description: Al Biles (a human trumpet player) & GenJam (the Genetic Jammer) play straight up jazz. They improvise on all kinds of tunes, and carry on a musical conversation, just like all good jazz soloists. GenJam, however, is software that evolves its musical ideas in real time as it listens to Al. Their repertoire includes Miles, Monk, Messengers, mambo, mainstream, modern, movie music, and more! Stop by to listen. Bring your ax and sit in! Watch Al's and GenJam's notes float by on the big screen!!
computerZone.exhibitors: Al Biles

computerZone.name: Algorave: Creating Dance Music with Code
computerZone.description: Live coding is an experimental performance practice where musicians/coders create music by coding it in front of an audience. The generated source code is projected for audience members to see. An Algorave is to the live coder what a rave is for a DJ; an event held at a club where live coders take turns performing one after another creating algorithmic dance music by coding it.
computerZone.exhibitors: Charles Roberts

computerZone.name: Analog Student Games Showcase
computerZone.description: Check out the analog games designed by students and faculty in the IGM program. Participate in hands-on demos and discussions on prototyping and development of tabletop and board games.
computerZone.exhibitors: Sean Boyle, Ryan Muskopf, David Erbelding, Reuben Brenner-Adams, Michael Howlett, Brandon Rodriguez, Collin Zanche, Connor Cummings

computerZone.name: Augmented Reality Chess Game
computerZone.description: Play a game of augmented reality chess game with friends not present at the same physical location as you are.
computerZone.exhibitors: Niyati Shah, Tanvi Raut

computerZone.name: Automatic Sentry Turret
computerZone.description: Demonstration of a Automatic Sentry Turret which is used to for securing an area against unauthorized people.
computerZone.exhibitors: Nicholas Freville

computerZone.name: Big Top - A Four Player Circus Game
computerZone.description: Big Top is a four player drafting and crafting card game about creating showpieces for the circus so that you can claim the title of Entertainer Extraordinaire.
computerZone.exhibitors: Oliver Barnum, Chase Slatterly, Matt Sahlin

computerZone.name: Blackfeather
computerZone.description: A video game where players take the role of a parrot who can control any pirate it perches upon. The parrot's goal is simple, find a way to keep a treasure to itself.
computerZone.exhibitors: Jessica Bayliss, David Chang, Kevin Idzik, Josh Malmquist, Sachit Puri, Joel Shuart, Charles Williams, Gregory Kriesel, Marla Schweppe

computerZone.name: BRICK: A Game of Networking and Subterfuge
computerZone.description: Nearables is aiming to make laser phone tag cheap and easy to set up for laser tag enthusiast of all types combined with a solid game design to bring everyone's favorite game modes.
computerZone.exhibitors: Alexia Bernardo, Matthew Crocco, Eileen Tea, Sameen Luo, Nicole Lopez

computerZone.name: Circular Gallifreyan Workshop
computerZone.description: We will be teaching people how to do Circular Gallifreyan, which is a fictional language based on the show Doctor Who. This activity is focused on teaching kids primarily but is open to all ages. There will be lots of pieces of paper and pencils for people to practice on.
computerZone.exhibitors: Claire Noble, Cameron Bajus, Taylor Braun, Derek Witt, Ava Enoch, Kyle Flores, Akash Eldo

computerZone.name: Computational Thinking with Life-Size Mazes
computerZone.description: Did you realize that when you solve a maze or other puzzle, you are thinking like a computer? Any series of steps taken to solve a problem is an algorithm, whether it is a human algorithm or a computer algorithm! In our exhibit, you will have the chance to solve some life-size mazes by walking around, and we will have other puzzles to solve as well. We will also discuss our related research in which we use puzzles as a way to teach computational thinking at RIT.
computerZone.exhibitors: Zack Butler, Ivona Bezakova, Eero Kelly, Misha Belisle, Liz Lucas, Alex Hoover, Samantha Oxley, Dana Adylova, Angelina Davern, Zack Fitzsimmons, David Narvaez, Stefan Aleksic

computerZone.name: Computing in Language Science Classrooms with Linguine
computerZone.description: Demonstration of how RIT language science coursework uses computational tools with visualizations for exploring linguistic concepts and data analysis.
computerZone.exhibitors: Cecilia O. Alm, Emily Prud'hommeaux

computerZone.name: Cosplay Troupe's Mini-Cosplay Experience
computerZone.description: Cosplay is quickly becoming a recognized term. Think of it as Halloween dressing up whenever you feel like. This activity is catered towards children, but anyone can participate. There will be materials, supplies, and several experienced cosplayers that will help you dress up and look like your favorite characters using limited supplies. You don't need a lot of cosplay. There will be a photo booth setup where you can take your photo afterwards with your finished creation.
computerZone.exhibitors: Joseph Oh, Erin McAnany, Andrew Iacovino, Ying Sin Gladys Leung, Du Giang

computerZone.name: Covert Channels in Cryptocurrency Protocols
computerZone.description: Exhibit will display research that has been done in identifying and documenting covert channels which exist as part of the Bitcoin cryptocurrency protocol, as well as comparing and contrasting other protocols to Bitcoin through the lens of suitability as a means for transmitting covert data.
computerZone.exhibitors: Alex Hew, Daryl Johnson

computerZone.name: Electro-Luminescent Organ (ELO)
computerZone.description: A restored and revamped vintage home organ, complete with a lightshow.
computerZone.exhibitors: Zachary Hart

computerZone.name: Elements
computerZone.description: A VR turn-based game using the HTC Vive where players explore a hex world and combat enemies.
computerZone.exhibitors: Jessica Bayliss, Feitong Chen, Sitong Chen, Reina Helms, Andrew Schoolnick, Lauren Sebaugh, Daniel Timko, Zach Welch, Marla Schweppe

computerZone.name: Event Analysis of Public Government Pentest Logs
computerZone.description: Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL) has released to the public a data set of a penetration test performed on its corporate, internal computer network. There are 5 data sources containing 58 days worth of de-identified data. The dataset is unique because it shows a US Federal Government facility being attacked by a Red Team. [2] Elasticsearch, Logstash, and Kibana (ELK), Splunk, and IBM's QRadar which will be explored, architected, deployed, and compared by analyzing the same LANL dataset.
computerZone.exhibitors: Scott Chapman

computerZone.name: EVF - Bring Vulnerabilities to the Classroom
computerZone.description: Come join us in Golisano Room 1469!
computerZone.exhibitors: Daryl Johnson, Corinne Smith, Michael Zobel, Bill Stackpole

computerZone.name: Experiments in Virtual Reality Game Design
computerZone.description: A showcase of several Virtual Reality experiences, each exploring a new mechanic or design pattern made possible by current VR technology.
computerZone.exhibitors: Bennett Samuels, Satchi Davis, Yanting Cheung, Ian Schreiber, Matthew Pressman

computerZone.name: Graphful : Art through code
computerZone.description: Art and science don't have to be different. Through the use of a new data language, any creative individual can leave an artistic expression.
computerZone.exhibitors: Nikhil Verma

computerZone.name: How Can Technology Empower Everyone?
computerZone.description: The main objective of this exhibit is to raise awareness of software accessibility. Accessibility is about enabling people of all abilities to have equal access to information needed for work and life. In this exhibit, attendees will interact with a mobile app that simulates the experience of users with visual impairment. This helps attendees develop a real empathy for users and a deeper understanding of how physical, cognitive and situational disabilities affect daily life activities.
computerZone.exhibitors: Yasmine Elglaly, Anthony Peruma, Scott Hawker, Stephen Cioffi

computerZone.name: Investigating Android M Permissions
computerZone.description: Android apps operate under a permission-based system where an app requires specific permissions to carry out specific functionality. In Android's new permission model (Android 'M'), users are no longer expected to confirm or deny all requested permissions upon installation of the application. The app may now prompt users during runtime for permissions as they are needed. This allows users to confirm or deny specific permission requests, but still be able to use the app. However, these profound changes lead to some challenging questions, one of which is if users feel more comfortable with this new permission model, or if it will lead to further confusion and concerns over the app's requested permissions?
computerZone.exhibitors: Daniel Krutz

computerZone.name: Jerusalem VR Experience
computerZone.description: Visit Jerusalem in the 1900's! At our booth we provide a unique virtual reality experience where users can view stereographs from the 1900's via Google Cardboard.
computerZone.exhibitors: Jacob Westerback, Chris Littlefield, Jeremy Astolfi, Ryan Flanagan, James Sasson, Stephen Jacobs, Matt Dieselman

computerZone.name: Kill the Streamer
computerZone.description: Kill the Streamer is a game between a streamer on Twitch, and their viewers talking in chat. Spawn enemies by messaging commands on Twitch. Try to work together to destroy your opponent-- the person streaming the game. You can play at twitch.tv/killthestreamergame, from any computer or even your phone! If you're the kind of player who wants a challenge, then come to our exhibit and play the game on our computer. See how long you can last against the horde!
computerZone.exhibitors: Luna Meier, Rochelle Cohn, Daniel Lowery, Rebecca Wengert, Ryan Jones, Luke Zetterlund

computerZone.name: Off the Wall
computerZone.description: Join us in room 1460 in Golisano!
computerZone.exhibitors: Ian Schreiber

computerZone.name: Pachink-Off - A Head to Head Gambling Game
computerZone.description: Do you love the head to head competitive rush of a fighting game? Do you love the thrill of gambling? Get ready to enter the exciting world of Pachink-Off! Pachink-Off is a mobile slots game, but no money is involved; the only goal is to get more tokens than your opponent! Go head to head with another player as unique and wacky characters as you engage in a fast paced gambling duel!
computerZone.exhibitors: Joel Tom, Michael Cohen

computerZone.name: Practical Ransomware Detection
computerZone.description: Presentation of a tool used to detect encrypting malware - known as Ransomware - through the use of system and process based information.
computerZone.exhibitors: Christopher Lazarus, Kyle Klatt

computerZone.name: Project Betrayal
computerZone.description: Project Betrayal is a 3D escape adventure where players progress through a building room by room solving puzzles in order to find out what happened.
computerZone.exhibitors: Jessica Bayliss, Hajime Agresta, Connor Chauncey, Ryan Jeter, Jacob Recoon, Stephanie Stoner, Trevor Walden, Yuchen Zhong, Marla Schweppe

computerZone.name: Raspberry Pi Arcade Table
computerZone.description: The Raspberry Pi Arcade Table Project is a mini arcade table using a Raspberry Pi and using Retro Pi. Children are free to play the games on the device with joysticks.
computerZone.exhibitors: Alexia Bernardo, David Quach, Lauren DiDonato, William Krodthoff, Makaya Hicks

computerZone.name: RITficial Intelligence
computerZone.description: Join us for RITficial Intelligence in Golisano room 1465.
computerZone.exhibitors: Dylan Bowald, Andy Meyer

computerZone.name: Sight: A VR Horror Experience
computerZone.description: A virtual reality horror game for the Oculus. The player's character is bound to a wheelchair and paranormal entities will show up in different situations leading to jump scares, chase scenes, etc. A hiding mechanic allows the player to hide from enemies. During gameplay, the player will have a constant feeling that something is behind them through effects such as breathing sounds, shadows, foot steps, mirror reflections, etc. A single level of the game will be playable at our exhibit.
computerZone.exhibitors: Sarathi Hansen, Jaben McCormack

computerZone.name: Society of Software Engineers Projects
computerZone.description: The Society of Software Engineers is proud to present a showcase of our projects from the most recent school year. Exhibits are both interactive and informative, with project creators available to answer questions. Projects include an interactive sandbox, remotely controlled jukebox computer, and various web-based projects. Feel free to ask in-depth technical questions and to play with the exhibit.
computerZone.exhibitors: Robert McLaughlin, Christina Howard, Michael Timbrook, Stephen Cioffi, Kevin Hannigan, Daniel Gude, Michael Longley, Kayla Davis, Joseph De Simpliciis, Benjamin Alderfer, Dylan Vuz, Kevin Arnett, Bill Dybas, Javis Johnson, Curtis Shea

computerZone.name: taskIt
computerZone.description: taskIt is simple and intuitive productivity app which helps to organize your life. You can add your tasks, both standalone or in the form of events, which group several tasks. taskIt enables you to sync events between your friends so that you can collectively be productive!
computerZone.exhibitors: Mitchell Sweet

computerZone.name: Team Based Fighting Game - Chosen Fate
computerZone.description: Our game Chosen Fate is a team based platform fighter. Players will choose from a number of weapons, armor, fighting styles, and special techniques to create their own personalized character. They then head into battle, either online or in local play. Contenders will work together to secure the enemy team's flag, and take down anyone who stands in their way!
computerZone.exhibitors: D'yangelo Grullon, Antwan Russell, Trinh Le, Nicholas Barlow

computerZone.name: Undergraduate Research in Computational Sensing
computerZone.description: This exhibit will disseminate information about the interdisciplinary REU Program in Computational Sensing. Visitors may experience sensing devices, posters, materials about the site (flyers, applications, information materials).
computerZone.exhibitors: Cecilia O. Alm, Reynold Bailey

computerZone.name: VRoom - A VR Car Combat Game
computerZone.description: VRoom is a VR car combat game built for the HTC Vive. It uses 3D motion tracking to seat the players in a digital car, allowing them to experience a high-speed chase against an AI opponent. Visitors will be able to try out the VR experience, attempting to destroy their pursuer without losing their own car. Using the Vive, they'll get a seat behind the steering wheel and right into the action. Drive through the wasteland and destroy your pursuers in a quick, self-contained experience.
computerZone.exhibitors: Robert Bailey, Aidan Markham, Alia Gestl, Jeannette Forbes, John Fediaczko, John Palermo, Luke Hedrick, Noah Kellem, Elouise Oyzon

computerZone.name: WiC Networking Alumni App
computerZone.description: We are currently trying to create a WiC Alumni Networking app using React Native and the Realm database. The aim of the app is to be able to move some of the communication from our closed Facebook Group to the mobile app. This app will allow WiC members to interact with others with this platform.
computerZone.exhibitors: Alexia Bernardo, Regina Locicero, Abigail Tran, David Quach

computerZone.name: Al Biles & GenJam
computerZone.description: Al Biles (a human trumpet player) & GenJam (the Genetic Jammer) play straight up jazz. They improvise on all kinds of tunes, and carry on a musical conversation, just like all good jazz soloists. GenJam, however, is software that evolves its musical ideas in real time as it listens to Al. Their repertoire includes Miles, Monk, Messengers, mambo, mainstream, modern, movie music, and more!
